journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of Money, Credit and Banking

title-group.article-title: House Price Booms, Current Account Deficits, and Low Interest Rates

abstract.p: Domestic factors, such as credit and preference shocks, can explain the negative correlation between house prices and the current account in the U.S. and several other countries before the recent crisis. These shocks, however, cannot account for the fall of world real interest rates observed in the data. Expansionary monetary policy shocks in the U.S., coupled with exchange rate pegs to the dollar in emerging economies, are crucial to understanding the evolution of the real interest rate. Yet, monetary policy factors play virtually no role for house prices and the current account.

caption.p: Left Panel: U.S. Current Account Balance % of GDP (Left Axis) and Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) Existing One-Family House Price Index Deflated by Headline Consumer Price Index (CPI) (Right Axis, 2001q1 = 100). Right Panel: Percentage Changes in Current Account % of GDP and in Real House Prices for Advanced and Emerging Economies between 2001 and 2006.

Top Panel: U.S. Short-Term Real Interest Rate (Nominal 1-Year T-Bill Yield Minus Expected Inflation from the Survey of Professional Forecasters). Bottom Panel: U.S. Long-Term Real Interest Rate at Different Maturities (Implied from Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities).
Real House Prices in the Model (for Different Values of β) in Response to LTV Shocks (Marked Solid Line), and in the Data (Dashed Line).
Real House Prices in the Model in Response to LTV Shocks (Solid Line with Diamonds) and Preference Shocks (Solid Line with Stars), and in the Data (Dashed Line).
Simulated Path of Real House Prices (Top), Current Account in % of GDP (Center), and Real Interest Rate (Bottom), in the Baseline Scenario (Solid Line), and in the Data (Dashed Line).
Nominal Interest Rate Predicted by a Taylor Rule with (Solid Line with Diamonds) and without (Solid Line with Stars) Smoothing, and in the Data (Dashed Line).

Simulated Path of Real House Prices (Top), Current Account in % of GDP (Center), and Real Interest Rate (Bottom), in the Baseline Scenario (Solid Line) and in the Baseline Scenario Plus Monetary Policy Shocks (Dashed Line).
Bilateral U.S. Trade Balance % of GDP by Area.

Simulated Path of Real House Prices (Top), Current Account in % of GDP (Center), and Real Interest Rate (Bottom) in the Baseline Scenario Plus Monetary Policy Shocks under a Flexible Exchange Rate Regime (Dashed Line), a Pure Foreign Peg (Solid Line with Diamonds), and a Dirty Foreign Peg (Solid Line with Stars).
